utterance: No, no, no! There shall be no kings or queens in Merrigoland. We will teach you all that we know, and you shall teach us all that you know, and so we will help each other; and no one shall think himself better than any one else, or forget that none of us can do well without the help of all the rest.
speaker: Peter Phinn and Merry Phinn

utterance: Hurrah for Peter and Merry, and down with fine ways and fine clothes!
speaker: the children

utterance: We could teach them nothing better than what they are learning for themselves. We may let them alone.
speaker: the fathers and mothers, and grandpas and grandmas, and uncles and aunts, and brothers and sisters

utterance: Tea is ready, Mrs. Legrange
speaker: James

utterance: And I must go and lie down a little before I dress for dinner. So, Sunshine, I shall leave you here alone, if you will promise not to touch any thing you should not, or to go too near the fire.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: Dear, dear, what a careless child!
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: But it ain't any matter, I guess, for I sha'n't have any under-sleeve to my gingham dress. Susan's aunt doesn't.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Now I's decent, and the cold won't catch me.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: What's the matter, young one?
speaker: the old woman

utterance: I don't know the way home, and I'm lost!
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Lost, be you? And where'd you git this 'ere pretty shawl?
speaker: the old woman

utterance: It's my mamma's, and you'd better not touch it; you might soil it, you know.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance:
Heh! Why, I guess you're a little lady, ain't you?
B'long to the big-bugs, don't you?
speaker: the old woman

utterance: I don't know. I want to go home.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Well, you come right in here along o' me, and wait till I get my pack off; then I'll show you the way home.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: You stop right there till I get a light. Don't ye budge now.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: Yes, you kin let me have that pooty shawl, little gal, cause Eh, what fine clo'es we've got on!
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
Now look at here, young un.
Them ain't your clo❜es; you know they ain't. You stole 'em.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: Stealed my clothes! Why, no, I didn't. Mamma gave them to me, and Susan sewed them.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance:
No sech a thing, you young liar!
You stole 'em ; and I'm a-going to take 'em off, and give you back your own, or some jist like 'em. Then I'll carry these fine fixings to the one they b'long to. Strip off, I tell yer. Come, now, no blubbering.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: Hi, hi! What sort o' gimcrack you got here?
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
Hi! that's pooty!
Now, what a young wretch you be for to go and say that ere's yourn!
speaker: the old woman

utterance: It is, it is mine! Papa gave me both of them, 'cause it's my birthday. They're my bracelets; only mamma said I was too little to wear them on my arms like she does, and she tied up my sleeves with them.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Where's t'other one, then?
speaker: the old woman

utterance: It's at home. I pulled it off 'cause I was going to be like Merry, that weared a sun-bonnet, and didn't have any bracelets.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Sun-bonnet! What d'ye want of a sun-bonnet, weather like this? I'll give you my old hood; that's more like it, I reckon.
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
No, I guess you'd better give me my own very clo'ses, and carry me home.
Then mamma will give me a gingham dress and a sun-bonnet; and maybe she'll give you my pretty things, if you want them.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Thanky for nothing, miss. I reckon it'll be a saving of trouble to take 'em now. I don't b'lieve a word about your ma'am giving 'em to you; and, more'n all, I don't b'lieve you've got no ma'am.
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
See! I've got your own clo'es here all ready for you.
Ain't I good?
speaker: the old woman

utterance: They ain't my clothes: I won't have 'em on. Go away, you naughty lady, you ain't good a bit!
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Come, come, miss, none o' them airs! Take that, now, and mend your manners!
speaker: the old woman

utterance: Now the Lord doesn't love you. Did you know it was the bad spirits that made you strike me? Mamma said so when I struck Susan.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Shut up! I don't want none of your preaching, miss. Here, put on these duds about the quickest, or I'll give you worse than that. Lor, what a mess of hair! What's the good on't? Maybe, though, they'd give some'at for it to the store.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: There, now, you'll do, I guess; and we'll go take you home only mind you don't speak a word to man, woman, nor child, as we go; for, if you do, I'll fetch you right back here, and shut you up with Old Bogy in that closet.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: Will you really take me home?
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: There, now! What did I tell yer? Now come along, and I will give you to Old Bogy.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: No, no! oh, please, don't! I will be good. I won't say a word any more. I forgotten that time, I did.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Well, then, don't go into fits, and I'll let you off this time; but see that you don't open your head agin, or it'll be all up with yer.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: Yes'm.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Hullo, Mother Winch! What's up to-night?
speaker: the policeman

utterance: Nothing, yer honor, - nothing at all. Me and little Biddy Mahoney's going to leave some duds at the pawnbroker's for her mother, who's most dead with the fever.
speaker: Mother Winch

utterance: Well, well, go along; only look out you carry no more than you honestly come by.
speaker: the policeman

utterance: Hold up, can't ye, gal! Or, if you're so tired as all that, set down on that door-stone, and wait for me a minute.
speaker: Mother Winch

utterance: I guess you have come after me, pretty bracelet, hasn't you? and we'll go home together.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Pretty stars, please tell God I'm lost. I think he doesn't know about it, or he'd send me home.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: THERE, honey! and I couldn't have done better by that buzzum if ye'd been the Prisidint.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss
addressee: the absent owner of the garments

utterance: And sure it's many a maner man they've made their prisidints out on, and sorra a better one they'd find betune here and Canady. It's yees that have the free hand and the kind way wid yees, for all your grand looks. The good Lord save and keep ye all the days of yer life!
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss
addressee: the absent owner of the garments

utterance:
And it's late ye're agin, Teddy Ginniss, bad 'cess to yees!
And thin it's mesilf that should take shame for saying it; for niver a b'y of them all is so good to his ould mother, and niver a one of 'em all that his mother's got so good a right to be proud on, as Ted. But where is the cratur? His supper's cowld as charity wid stannin.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Teddy, b'y, an' is it yersilf?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Yes, mother, its meself.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Saints an' angels, child! and what have ye got there?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: It's a little girl, mother; and I'm feared she's dead!
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: A little girl, an' she's dead! Oh, wurra, wurra, Teddy Ginniss, that iver I should be own mother to a murtherer! An' is it yersilf that kilt the purty darlint?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Meself, mother!
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Sure and it wasn't; and I wouldn't 'a thought you'd have needed to ask. I found her on a doorstep in Tanner's Court and first I thought she was asleep, and so I shook her to tell her to go home before the Charley got her; and then, when she wouldn't wake up, I saw she was either fainted or dead; and I fetched her home to you, — and it's you that go for to call me a murtherer! Oh, oh!
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Whisht, honey, whisht! And it's an ould fool I am wid me fancies an' me frights. But let us look at the poor little crather ye've brought home to me. Sure and it was like yees, Teddy, b'y.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Oh, thin! an' it's a shame to see the purty darlint lay like that; and I'm 'feared, unless the breath's in her yet, she's dead intirely.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Maybe it's only the cold and the hunger that's ailing her, and she'll come to with the fire and vittels. She can have my supper and my breakfast too, and a welcome with it.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: The cowld, maybe, it is; for her clothes is nixt to nothing, an' the flesh of her's like a stone wid the freezing: but she's got enough to ate, or she never'd be so round an' plump. It's like she's the child of some beggar-woman that's fed her on broken vittels, an', whin she got tired ov trampin' wid her, jist dropped her on the doorstep where yees got her. Howly mother! what's this?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: An' where did this splindid armlit come from, Teddy Ginniss?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Sorra a bit of me knows, thin; an' is it a thafe ye'll be callin' me as well as a murtherer!
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Whisht, ye spalpeen! an' lave it on the mantletry till we see if the breath's in her yit. Sure an' sich a little crather niver could have stole it.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Power some warm wather into the biggest wash-tub, Teddy, an' I'll thry puttin' her in it. It's what the Yankee 57 doctor said to do wid yees, whin yees had fits; an' it niver did no harm, anyways.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Is it a fit she's got?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: The good Lord knows what's she's got, or who she is. Mabbe the good folk put her where yees got her. Niver a beggar-brat before had a skin so satin-smooth, an' hands an' feet like rose-leaves and milk. An' look how clane she is from head to heel! Niver a corpse ready for the wakin' was nater.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: The water's ready now.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Glory be to God an' to his saints! The purty crather's alive, and lookin' at me wid the two blue eyes av her like a little angel! Han' me the big tow'l till I rub her dhry.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: She's alive, she's alive! and she'll be my little sister, and we'll keep her always, won't we, mother?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Wait, thin, till we see if it's here she is in the morning.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: And where else would she be, if not here?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: If it war the good folks* that browt her, it's they that will fetch her away agin 'fore the daylight. Wait till mornin', Teddy darlint.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: AND is she here, mother?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Yis, b'y, she's here; but it's not long she'll be, savin' the mercy o' God. It's the heavy sickness that's on her the morn.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: And will she die, mother?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: The good Lord knows, not the likes of me, Teddy darlint.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: And you'll keep her, and do for her, mother, won't you?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Sure and it wouldn't be Judy Ginniss that'd turn out a dying child, let alone sending her to te poor'us. Thim that sint her to us will sind us the manes to kape her.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Here's the masther's shirts done, Teddy; and ye'd betther take thim to his lodgings before yees go to the office. More by token, it's him as u'd tell us what we'd ought to be doin' wid the darlint, if she lives, or if she dies. Tell the masther all ye know uv her, Teddy; an' ax him to set us sthraight.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: No, no, mother! I'll be doing no such thing: for it's ourselves wants her, and any thing the master would say would tak
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: It is Tom, and he has news!
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: Aren't these her clothes?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Yes, yes! O Tom! where is she? Tell me quick, before my poor heart breaks with joy!
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: Where did you get them, Tom?
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: Good-by, dear cousin Fanny!
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Good-by, Tom! and oh, pray, do every thing, every thing, that can be done! I cannot tell
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: She must have been carried from the city.
speaker: the detectives

utterance: Any one been in this morning, Teddy?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: No, sir.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: I am going out of town for a day or two, Teddy, — going 92 93 to New York; and Mr. Barlow will be here to attend to the business. You will do whatever he wishes as you would You understand?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Aren't you well, Teddy?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Yes, sir, thank your honor.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Not 'your honor' until I'm a judge, Teddy. But what's amiss with you, my boy?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: I wouldn't be troubling your-you with it, sir. It's nothing as can be helped.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: No, no; but what is it, Teddy?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Nothing, sir; but the little sister is mortal sick, and the doctor says he's afeard she won't stand it.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Your little sister, Teddy?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: I didn't know you before, did you?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Maybe not, sir.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: What is the matter with her?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: The faver, sir.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Typhus! I'm sorry for you, Teddy, and sorry, too, for your mother, who is an excellent woman; but the little girl may yet recover: while there is life, there is hope, you know. Even if she dies, it is not so bad asgoing to New York, Teddy, to look for a little cousin of mine whose parents do not know if she is living or dead, suffering or safe: that is worse than to have her ill, but under their care and protection, isn't it?
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: Yes, sir, perhaps. Is the little girl in New York, sir, do you think?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: We hear of a child found astray there, who answers to the description; and I am going to see her before we mention the report to her mother. Have you never seen Mr. Legrange here, Teddy? It is his little girl. I wonder haven't heard us talking of the matter.
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: I don't mind the name, sir; and I haven't heard of the little girl before. Is she long lost?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Ten days yesterday. I have been busy all the week in the search for her. The clothes she had on when lost were 95 found in a pawn-broker's shop; but we have no trace of her yet.
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: What looking child was she, if you please, sir?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Toinette? Here is a description of her in 'The Journal,' and I have a photograph in my pocket-book. Here it is. It is well for you to study them both; for possibly you may discover her. I didn't think of it before; but you are just the boy to put upon the search. If you should find her, Teddy, Mr. Legrange will make your fortune. He is rich and generous, and this is his only child. Eleven o'clock. Shall be in at one.
speaker: Mr. Burroughs

utterance: I'll lose her anyway, if she dies or if she lives; and it's all the little sister ever I got.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: It's the big fool I am, entirely ! Sure and mightn't she have picked up the bracelet in the street, where maybe the little lady they've lost dropped it? And, if she looks like the picture, so does many a one beside; and it's no call I have 97 to be troubling the master with telling him about her anyway. She's my own little sister, and I'll keep her to myself.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Leastways, I'll keep her if God will let me; and sure isn't he stronger nor me? If it isn't for me to have her, can't he take her, if it's by death, or if it's by leading them that's searching for her to where she is? And more by token, that's the way I'll try it. If God means she shall stay and be my little sister, she'll live, and I'll take her, and say nothing to nobody about it: but, if it's displasin' to him, she'll die; and then I'll tell the master all about it, and he may do what he's a mind to with me. That's the way I'll fix it.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: O God! let her live, and I will give her back to them as I kept her from.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: She will live, with God's help, and the best of care from you.
speaker: Dr. Wentworth

utterance: An' it's the bist uv care she'll git, I'll pass me word for that.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Hush! She is falling asleep. Do not wake her, for her life!
speaker: Dr. Wentworth

utterance: She is doing well. Keep her as quiet as possible. I will be in at nine.
speaker: Dr. Wentworth

utterance: An' it's waker an' whiter she gits every day. Sure and I'm afther seeing the daylight through the little hands uv her; and her eyes is that big, they take the breath uv me whin I mate 'em. See, darlint! see the purty skip-jack Teddy brought ye!
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Have a soop of yer dhrink, darlint?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: An' what is it I'll plaze ye wid, mavourneen? Do yees want Teddy to coom home?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: It's this minute he'll be here, thin, An' faith yees ought to love him, honey; for he'd give the two eyes out of his head to plaze yees, an' git down on his knees to thank yees for takin' 'em. Now, thin, don't ye hear his fut upon the stair?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: And it's Jovarny it wor that time, honey, but Teddy'll coom nixt; see if he doun't, Cherry darlint.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Mamma, mamma! I'm Cherritoe! and I can dance with that music, and mamma can play it more
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Go an' shtop that fool's noise if yees brain him, an' ax him what's the name o' that divil's jig he's playing!
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: It's the cachuca, mother; but what's the matter with the little sister?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Whist! She's swounded wid the noise he's afther making.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Where's the music, mammy?
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: The music, darlint? And what music do ye be manin'?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: The music I heard one day before I went to heaven. Didn't you hear it?
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: An' whin did ye go to hivin, ye quare child?
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Oh! I don't know. When I came back, I was sick in the bed. I want the music, mammy.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: It's Jovarny she manes, the little crather.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Where's the music, Teddy? Mammy said you'd get it for me.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: It's Jovarny she's afther wantin' to hear play on his grind-orgin; an' I towld her he'd coom whin yees did.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Oh! may she?
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: Thin agin, maybe the bit moonkey ud scare her back into the fayver as bad as iver.
speaker: Mrs. Ginniss

utterance: Thank you, little brother. I'll eat my supper for you now.
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: Let her come down and see the organ and Pantalon.
speaker: Giovanni

utterance: Be you raound here, Harnah, or Seth?'
speaker: unnamed character

utterance: Yes, we be,'
speaker: Seth

utterance: We must git her out o' this horrid den 'fore she knows whar she is, or it'll skeer her to death,'
speaker: Seth

utterance: But how'll we do it?'
speaker: Seth

utterance: You look as if you b'longed here; so I reckon you'd better stop behind, and I'll git Harnah out by myself,'
speaker: Sam Hedge

utterance: Well, what next, Seth?
speaker: Karl

utterance:
Nothing, cap'n: that's all; except I didn't tell how Sam see me going up the river, and suspicioned I wor a going to meet Harnah, and so dropped all, and followed on.
What he brought his gun fer, I didn't never ask him.
speaker: Seth

utterance: But Hannah what became of her?
speaker: unnamed character

utterance: Oh! she was kind o' peeked a while, with her broken leg; but, arter that, she was as well as ever.
speaker: Seth

utterance: Yes; but how did her love-affairs terminate?
speaker: Karl

utterance:
Waal, she married Sam Hedge the next fall; and I guess their love-affairs turned out like other folkses a good deal, - lots o' 'lasses at fust, and, arter a while, lots o'
vinegar: that's the way o' merried life.
speaker: Seth

utterance: Oh, waal!'
speaker: Mehitable Ross

utterance: I don't know as I've any call to find fault with merried life. Seth's made as good a husband as a gal has a right to expect that takes a feller out o' pity 'cause he's been mittened by another gal.
speaker: Mehitable Ross

utterance: Fanny what is it?
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: That letter you have some news! O Paul, you have news of
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance:
No, darling, no news of her,-not yet, at least.
What made you fancy it? This is only a letter from your protégé at Antioch College: at least, I suppose so from the postmark.
Do you care to read it now?
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance:
O Paul! when I heard you coming up the stairs, such a feeling came over me! I seemed to feel some great revelation approaching. I was sure it was news of her.
Paul, Paul, I cannot bear it; I cannot live! My heart is broken; but it will not die, and let me rest. O my God! how long?
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: Hush, dearest, hush! Your wild words are to me worse than the grief we both suffer so keenly. But, my wife, have we not each other? and would you kill me by your own despair? Will God be pleased, that, because he has taken away our Sunshine, we refuse all other blessings, and disdain all other ties and obligations? Fanny, dearest, is it not an earnest duty with you to strive for strength?
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: O Paul! do not try, do not talk: it is useless. When you let fall that crystal vinaigrette this morning, did you tell it that its duty was to be whole, and filled with perfume again? Do you tell those flowers that it is their duty to be fresh and sweet as they were yesterday? or, if you did, would they heed you?
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: No, darling; for they have neither mind nor soul,'
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: And mine are swallowed up in the sorrow that has swallowed all else. O Paul! forgive me, and ask God to forgive me; but I cannot, I never can, become resigned. I cannot live; I cannot wish or try to live. A little while, and I shall see her.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: From whom did you say the letter came, Paul?
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: From Theodore Ginniss, I believe. Will you read it now?
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: Yes: I told him to write to me once in every month, and he is very punctual.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance:
DEAR MRS. LEGrange, — "Since writing to you last month, I have been going on with my studies under the Rev. Mr. Brown, as I then mentioned. I do not find that it hurts me to study in the hot weather at all; and I have enjoyed my vacation better this way than if I had been idle.
Part of the month, however, Mr. Brown has been away on a visit to some friends in Iowa; and he says so much about the prairies, and the great rivers, and the wild life out there, that I think I should like to take the two remaining weeks of the vacation, and go and see them, if you have no objection. I have a great plenty of money from my last quarter's allowance, as I have only needed to spend a dollar and forty-five cents. Mr. Brown thinks I should come back fresher to my studies for a little rest; though I do not feel the need of it, and am glad of every day's new chance of learning.
I hope you will excuse me, Mrs. Legrange, if it is too bold for me to say, but I do wish you could talk with Mr.
Brown a little; he is so high in all his ideas, and seems to feel so strong about all the troubles of this world, and puts what a man ought to live for so much above the way he has to live!
I took the liberty of talking with him about you, and about the great trouble I had helped to bring upon you; and what he said was first-rate, though I cannot tell it again.
I felt ever so much better about my own doing wrong, and I could not help wishing you could hear what he said about you.
This place is a great resort for invalids, and people who like to be retired. The iron-springs, that give the name to
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance:
the town, are said to be very strengthening; and the Neff House, near them, is a beautiful hotel in very romantic scenery, and quite still. It seems to me that the ladies I see riding out from it on horseback get healthier-looking every day.
I enclose a letter for mother, and will ask of you the favor to read it to her. I cannot tell you, Mrs. Legrange, how grateful I feel to you for making her so comfortable, as well as for what you are doing for me. And it is not only you I thank and remember every morning and every night; but, with yours, I say the name of the angel that we both love so dear.
Yours respectfully, THEODORE GINNISS.
speaker: Theodore Ginniss

utterance: I should like to see this Mr. Brown. Perhaps he has some comfort for me; and that was what I felt approaching in that letter.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: I am afraid, love, you would be disappointed. A man might seem a marvel of eloquence and wisdom to poor Theodore, while you would find him a very commonplace, perhaps obtrusive individual.
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: I feel just as if that man could give me comfort. I must see him.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance:
Very well, dear: if it will give you the slightest pleasure, you shall certainly do so. Shall I send and invite him here?
or do you think the journey to Ohio would be a pleasant variety for you? Perhaps it might; and Teddy's elaborately artless recommendation of the Neff House and the ironsprings is worthy of some attention.
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: Yes: I will go there. I think I should like the journey, and I don't object to trying the springs; and I should like to see Theodore, and hear him talk about her. And I am sure I shall not find Mr. Brown commonplace or obtrusive.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance:
Very well, dear: it shall be as you say.
When shall we go? It will be very hot travelling now, I am afraid.
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: Oh, no! I don't mind. But I don't want to interfere with the Western excursion Theodore so modestly suggests; nor do I wish to go while he is away. We will go in the middle of September, I think.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: Yes, that will do, and will give you something to be thinking of meantime,'
speaker: Mr. Legrange

utterance: go and send Mrs. Ginniss up to me to hear her letter too, — that is, if you please; for, you humor me so much, I know I am growing tyrannical in speech as well as in act.
speaker: Mrs. Legrange

utterance: And if you feel able to ride so far, Dora,'
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: perhaps you will show me the way to the curious mounds we heard of from Dr. Gershom.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: They are full ten miles from here, he said,'
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: To-day is the 24th, isn't it, Dora? the 24th of August?
speaker: Karl

utterance: Yes, Karl; it is the 24th: and I think we can make a party for the mounds, Mr. Brown. Kitty, wouldn't you like to go? and, Karl, can't you take a holiday? Sunshine might stay with Mehitable for once; mightn't she?
speaker: Dora Burroughs
addressee: Karl, Kitty Windsor, Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: No; because she speaks too loud, and through her nose: but I'll stay with Argus and the woods,'
speaker: Toinette Legrange

utterance: But have we horses enough?
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: That is easily settled,'
speaker: Karl

utterance:
I will fix Sunshine's pillion upon Major, and Dora can ride behind me.
Then Kitty can take Max, and Mr. Brown will ride his own horse.
speaker: Karl

utterance: Oh! there is no need of Major's carrying double,'
speaker: Dora Burroughs

utterance: Seth can spare Sally as well as not, and Kitty can ride her better than she can Max.
speaker: Dora Burroughs

utterance: I want to speak to you before we go.
speaker: Karl

utterance: Windsor, this is not soldierly or manly.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: We both know what is in the other's mind,'
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: and we know that we cannot both succeed; but that is no reason for ill feeling toward each other. If we were Don Quixotes, we might fight; if we were gamesters, we might throw for the first chance: but as we are, I trust, Christian gentlemen, we owe each other every kindly feeling short of a wish for success.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Yes: you can hardly expect that of me; and I'm sure I don't of you,'
speaker: Karl

utterance: No that were inconsistent with a true earnestness of purpose,'
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: And, after all, the girl we 325 both love is no such weakling as to accept a man simply because he asks her. She will decide between us fairly and justly.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Then let me have the first chance, since you think it no advantage,'
speaker: Karl

utterance: Is there not some proverb about age before merit?
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Besides, you have had more than four years to ask your question in, and can very well wait a few hours longer. I came to Iowa on purpose to ask mine, and shall go away to-morrow.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: I don't see, sir, but you saints are just as obstinate in getting what you want as we sinners,'
speaker: Karl

utterance: A man at thirty has seldom subdued his worldly passions and intentions to the degree of sainthood,'
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: And I will not deny that my heart is very much engaged in this matter. However, I will be generous, and you may take your chance first.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Are you pretty quick at hearing, Mr. Brown?
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: Not especially. Why?
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Oh! I thought you looked as if you would like to hear what Charlie is saying to Dora.
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: And you thought it was very rude of me to be so inattentive to you,'
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Oh dear, no! I'm used to finding myself of no account beside Dora.
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: Kitty, are you going to tell me, before I go away, what made you feel so badly the day I came and found you in the wood?
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: No one cares much for me, I think.
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: No one? - not your brother?
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: To wait for by and by, when some one else has done with him, is not my idea of love.
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: I think the day will come when some man will love you first and best of all,'
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Oh! I'm not good enough, or smart enough, or goodlooking enough. He never will,'
speaker: Kitty Windsor

utterance: He? Do you mean some one in particular? No: forgive me. I have no right to ask such a question. I am only your friend, not a father confessor.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Brown

utterance: Karl, be honest and straightforward. It is kinder to us both.
speaker: Dora Burroughs

utterance: That's it, Dora. There isn't another such girl in the world. Don't you know, in camp I used to say I relied upon you for protection, and for making a man of me instead of an idle boy? O Dora! there's nothing you couldn't do with me.
speaker: Karl

utterance:
It isn't any thing I can offer you, Dora, except the chance of doing good: I know that well enough. What I am, you know; but what I might become to please you, none of us can know. And I do love you so, Dora! I know it sounds bald and silly to say just these few words; but they mean so much to me! and I've meant it so long and so heartily! No; don't speak just yet: I want to make you feel first, if I can, how dreadfully in earnest I am. When I first saw you there at your old home, and you took care of me so tenderly, and looked at me so pityingly out of your great brown eyes, my heart warmed to you; and then in
--but camp, you know. O Dora Darling! you cannot say you knew how dearly I grew to love you even then: and when I found you were my own kin; and when you came to my own home, and my mother took you to her heart, and thanked God for having given her another daughter, and such a daughter; and when I saw your daily life among us, and saw how noble, and how unselfish, and how true and brave, you were through all the sorrow, and the trials, and the loneliness, and the petty spite and insults, you had to endure; and then here, where you are like a wise and gracious queen among her subjects, O Dora! what is there in you that does not call forth my highest love, my truest reverence? and what better could life do for me than to grant me the privilege of worshipping
speaker: Karl
